title: 113_s3000
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area Act of 2014" and includes definitions for key terms. The Act defines key terms such as Federal land, map, non-Federal land, proposed exchange parcel, Recreation Area, and Secretary. The Act defines key terms such as Federal land, map, non-Federal land, proposed exchange parcel, Recreation Area, Secretary, Secretary of the Interior, and State of Utah. SEC. 3. Establishes the Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah. Establishes the Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah, covering approximately 18,447 acres for recreational uses and off-highway vehicle activities. The area will be administered by the Secretary through the Bureau of Land Management. The Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah, covering 18,447 acres, will be administered by the Bureau of Land Management. Federal laws and land use plans will apply, with uses consistent with the area's purposes. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife is unaffected, and no protective buffer zones will be created. Off-highway vehicle use is permitted in the area. The Hurricane Sand Dunes National Recreation Area in Utah, covering 18,447 acres, will be administered by the Bureau of Land Management and remain open to off-highway vehicles in perpetuity. SEC. 4. EXCHANGE OF FEDERAL LAND AND NON-FEDERAL LAND. The Secretary must accept the State's offer to convey non-Federal land to the United States and then convey Federal land to the State. The exchange is subject to valid existing rights, and the title approval must be acceptable to both parties. Appraisals by independent appraisers will determine the value of the lands to be exchanged. The appraisals for the land exchange must be conducted by independent appraisers in accordance with national standards. The value of Federal and non-Federal land exchanged must be equal or adjusted to be equal. If Federal land value exceeds non-Federal land, equalization measures will be taken. If the value of Federal land exceeds non-Federal land, adjustments will be made to equalize their values through reducing acreage or adding State land. Conversely, if non-Federal land value surpasses Federal land, the acreage of non-Federal land will be reduced to achieve equalization. Upon conveyance to the Secretary, non-Federal land will be added to the Recreation Area and managed by the Secretary in accordance with the Federal Land Policy Act of 1976.
